content: If your client's mobile phone was stolen last Friday, they should take the following steps based on the information available GOMgBJgBBLViOYD198L: 1. Report the stolen phone to their network provider immediately. This allows the provider to block the phone and prevent unauthorised use. Failing to report promptly may result in charges for unauthorised calls.Qp7vZkLm8sXyTn2aWEr 2. Report the theft to the police. Your client should visit their local police station or call 101 to file a report. They will need to provide the phone's identification number (IMEI), which the network provider can supply.Ab3cDe4Fg5Hi6Jk7LmN 3. Get a crime reference number from the police. This will be required if your client needs to make an insurance claim for the stolen phone.

sources.title: If you think your ESA decision is wrong - mandatory reconsideration - Citizens Advice
Employment and Support Allowance (ESA) - Citizens Advice
If your ESA is stopped or reduced - Citizens Advice

content: If your client's Employment and Support Allowance (ESA) was stopped but the reason is unknown, they have a few key options: 1. Request a mandatory reconsideration Your client can ask the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) to reconsider their decision within 1 month of the decision date. They should explain why they disagree with the reasons given for stopping their ESA and provide any new evidence. YuMmBJgBBLViOYD1Uvxj 2. Make a new ESA claim If your client's condition has worsened or they have developed a new condition since the decision, they could make a new claim for ESA. This may allow them to start receiving payments sooner while awaiting the mandatory reconsideration outcome. YuMmBJgBBLViOYD1Uvxj 3. Check eligibility for other benefits If unable to get ESA reinstated, your client could check their potential eligibility for other income-based benefits like Universal Credit based on their current circumstances. oeMPBJgBBLViOYD1c8j3

Check if going bankrupt is right for you - Citizens Advice
Debt relief orders - what you need to know - Citizens Advice

content: For a client with a £13,000 debt, there are several potential options to consider based on the information available 3eMNBJgBBLViOYD1s8TV: Debt Management Plan (DMP): This allows the client to make one affordable monthly payment to a DMP provider, who distributes it to creditors. While it may take longer to pay back the debt, interest and charges may continue accruing. The DMP provider could charge a fee, but there are free options like those offered by charities like Citizens Advice dOQ-BJgBBLViOYD1OzWM. Debt Relief Order (DRO): If the client has a low income, little spare income, and assets under £1,000, they may qualify for a DRO. This freezes interest and charges for a year, after which the debt is written off if circumstances haven't improved. Bankruptcy: For larger debts where the client cannot afford payments, bankruptcy may be an option to write off most debts after assets are used to pay creditors. This has serious implications like losing assets and impacting credit rating. It's crucial the client seeks free, impartial debt advice from Citizens Advice or other charities to understand all options based on their full financial circumstances dOQ-BJgBLViOYD1OzWM.

Check if you've experienced a hate crime or hate incident - Citizens Advice
Discrimination because of sexual orientation - Citizens Advice

content: Based on the information available, your client has experienced a hate crime due to their sexuality. A hate crime is defined as a crime motivated by prejudice against someone's sexuality luQqBJgBBLViOYD1tAeR. As the incident occurred on Saturday night in Manchester city centre, there are support options your client can access: Reporting the incident: Your client can report the hate crime to the police, who must record it as a hate incident if they believe it was motivated by prejudice against their sexuality YuMVBJgBBLViOYD1_tfV. The police will provide an incident reference number and may investigate further if a crime has occurred. Victim support: The police can refer your client to Victim Support, an independent charity that provides emotional and practical support to victims of crime YuMVBJgBBLViOYD1_tfV. This could include help repairing any property damaged during the incident. Local support services: There may be local hate crime support services in Manchester that can provide specific advice and assistance for victims of hate crimes motivated by sexuality. The adviser could check what services are available in the local area.
